description: M. Joycelyn Elders was born in Schaal, Arkansas (Howard County). In 1952 she graduated from Philander Smith College with a B.S. in Biology. The following year she enlisted in the U.S. Army as a physical therapist and obtained the rank of 2nd Lieutenant. After her discharge, she enrolled at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences obtaining her medical degree in 1962. Dr. Elders is certified as a pediatric endocrinologist. She is an expert in childhood sexual development and juvenile diabetes. In 1987, Governor Bill Clinton asked her to serve as the Director of the Arkansas Department of Health. Elders was the first African American and first woman to direct the Arkansas public health service, a position she held for six years (1987-1993). In 1993, President Bill Clinton appointed her Surgeon-General of the United States. She became the first African American woman to be appointed Surgeon General of the U.S. Public Health Service, serving until December 1994. A lifetime of service, Dr. Elders faced throughout her career the challenges of the onset of the HIV/AIDS disease and the highest rate of teen pregnancy in the industrialized world. She steadfastly pursued to raise the awareness of sexual education and successfully reduced the rate of teenage pregnancies throughout the country. Among her many achievements, Dr. Joycelyn Elders was inducted into the Arkansas Black Hall of Fame in 1995 and the Arkansas Womens Hall of Fame in 2016.

title: Lena Lowe Jordan
description: Lena Lowe Jordan was an African-American registered nurse and hospital administrator. In the 1920s, she moved to Little Rock, Arkansas from the state of Georgia and began her career as a registered nurse at the Mosaic State Hospital in 1927. In the 1930s, Lena Jordan became affiliated with the Arkansas Home and Hospital for Crippled Negro Children in Little Rock, AR. The hospital was the only charitable institution that cared for crippled black children and operated with a small budget. By 1936, in considerable financial troubles, Lena Jordan placed a mortgage on her own home to keep the hospital in operation. Subsequently, the institution was renamed the Lena Jordan Hospital by 1938. Her hospital was a twenty-bed facility equipped for general surgery, medical, and obstetric care. It was open to all black patients, regardless of their ability to pay. The physicians who made up her staff worked without pay and for charity. Notably, Lena Jordan created a program at her hospital to train new nurses. She provided the opportunity for young women to gain work experience at the hospital and obtain a practical nursing certificate for their service. Lena Jordan spent over thirty years caring for the poor and underserved communities of Little Rock, Arkansas.

title: Kathryn Hall-Trujillo, Public Health Advocate
description: Dr. Kathryn Hall-Trujillo was born in Moscow, Arkansas (Jefferson County). She is a public health expert and advocate who focuses on healthcare for African American women. Hall-Trujillo received her M.A. in Public Health from the University of California at Los Angeles. In 1976, she worked as a public health administrator for the State of California. Seeing the difficulties that underserved women experienced in accessing quality health care, Hall-Trujillo established the Center for Community Health and Well-Being in 1988, a holistic health and social service agency based in Sacramento that housed a comprehensive health care clinic. Deriving from her work at the Center, Hall-Trujillo created the non-profit organization Birthing Project USA: The Underground Railroad for New Life, which has the goal of reducing infant mortality rates. From 1988 to 2010, her project helped 12,000 babies in over ninety-four communities in the United States, Canada, Cuba, Central America, and Africa. As faculty at the University of San Francisco, Dr. Hall-Trujillo is helping develop the Public Health Leadership Program for the Sacramento campus. In 2011, she was inducted into the Arkansas Black Hall of Fame.

title: Mamie Odessa Hale Garland, Midwife Consultant for the Arkansas Department of Health
description: Mamie Odessa Hale was born November 19, 1910 in Keeny's Creek, WV. She completed her early medical education at Freedman's Hospital, School of Nursing in Washington, D.C., and then worked for a time with the county health unit for the Works Progress Administration in Fayette County, WV. Prior to beginning her new career in Arkansas, she took a course on midwifery at the Tuskegee Institute in Tuskegee, AL. In 1942, Mamie Hale arrived in Arkansas where she helped local nurses administer midwife educational programs for the Crittenden County Health Department. By 1945, she was appointed as midwife consultant by the Arkansas Department of Health. Nurse Hale was responsible for the training of midwives across the state ensuring that they knew the proper techniques to manage the medical aspects of pregnancy. From 1945 to 1950, Mamie Hale initiated educational programs throughout Conway, Faulkner, Lonoke, and St. Francis counties. Her impactful contributions to nursing and midwife education led to a marked improvement in Arkansas' maternal and infant mortality rates.

title: Mamie Katherine Phipps Clark
description: Mamie Phipps Clark grew up in Hot Springs, Arkansas where she attended Langston High School. In 1934, after graduating at the age of seventeen, Clark was offered several scholarships to prominent black colleges. She chose Howard University in Washington D.C. majoring where she pursued studies in mathematics and physics. After graduating, Clark shifted her focus to psychology and enrolled in Columbia University, NY. In 1943, Clark completed her doctorate and was distinguished as being the first black woman to receive a degree in psychology at that institution. Her graduate research focused on the development of racial identity in children and was to prove influential in the Supreme Court ruling of Brown v Board of Education. In 1946, Dr. Clark and her husband opened the Northside Testing and Consultation Center in Harlem, New York. It was the first institutional practice in the area to offer psychological and casework services to local black families. In 1973, Mamie Phipps Clark was awarded the American Association of University Women Achievement Award and later the Candace Award for humanitarianism.

title: Freda McKissic Bush
description: Freda McKissic Bush, M.D., is an obstetrician/gynecologist with long experience in addressing issues of women's health. She often speaks on topics such as sexual health, sexually transmitted diseases, and social behavior education. Dr. Bush graduated from the University of Mississippi Medical School. In 1987, she completed her residency training at the University of Tennessee in Memphis. Since that time, Dr. Bush has practiced obstetrics and gynecology in Jackson, Mississippi and is a clinical instructor at the University of Mississippi Medical Center. In February 2012, she became President and CEO of the Medical Institute for Sexual Health. Dr. Bush is a member of the council for Focus on the Family. She serves as a medical advisor for Heartbeat International and CareNet and serves as Medical Director to the Center for Pregnancy Choices, Metro Jackson.

title: Dr. Florence Char, Pediatric Faculty
description: Florence Char was born in Peking, China on April 7, 1923. By the early 1940s, her parents sent Florence and her brother to live in the western United States. Dr. Char earned her medical degree at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn in 1952. She interned in Pediatrics at the University of Minnesota Hospitals from 1952-53 and was a fellow in Pediatric Cardiology in 1955-1957. She was certified in Pediatrics in 1959 and Pediatric Cardiology in 1965. She joined the faculty at the University of Arkansas School of Medicine in 1963. In 1971, Dr. Char established the first genetics clinics and cytogenetics laboratory in Arkansas and was instrumental in the creation of the Arkansas Genetics Program at UAMS. In 1978, Dr. Char described a genetic birth defect that came to be called Char syndrome. She retired in 1990 with the rank of professor emeritus.

title: Dr. Patricia A. Newton, Psychiatry
description: Patricia A. Newton, M.D., M.H.P., M.A. was born in Tuckerman, Arkansas. She was the medical director, a former president, and founding member of the Black Psychiatrists of America (BPA). She was one of the first APA/NIMH Fellows and the first woman chair of the Department of Psychiatry at Provident Hospital in Baltimore. Dr. Newton also served as academic faculty at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine for over sixteen years. Her clinical work centered on anxiety disorders with a special focus on posttraumatic stress disorder, as well as depression and chronic mental illness. Dr. Newton was renowned for her pioneering work integrating African spirituality into Black mental health and for working with health care professionals in Africa and the Caribbean as well as in the United States.

title: Lidia Gertrudis Sogandares, UAMS
description: A citizen of the Republic of Panama, Dr. Lidia Gertrudis Sogandares was the first Latin American graduate of the University of Arkansas School of Medicine. She is renown as the first female doctor in Panama and Central America. In 1934, Lidia Sogandares graduated from UAMS with a degree in medicine. She completed residency at the Women's Hospital in Philadelphia, where she specialized in the fields of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Returning to Panama, Dr. Sogandares joined the medical staff at Santos Tomas Hospital and gradually rose to the position of Chief of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Over the course of her career, Sogandares published several gynecological studies and was affiliated with many professional organizations. Dr. Lidia G. Sogandares was co-founder and first female member of the Panamanian Academy of Medicine and Surgery; She was a co-founder and the first president of the Panamanian Society of Obstetrics and Gynecology, a member of the Pan-American Alliance of Medical Women, the Isthmian Medical Association of the Canal Zone, and the Women Medical Association.

title: Bennie "Mama" McGuire, on a midwife appointment
description: Bennie "Mama" McGurie grew up on a farm in Hardemann County, TN. Inspired by her grandmother who had been a midwife, she learned midwife techniques from a rural doctor. Bennie McGurie moved to Marked Tree, Arkansas in 1914. She was to deliver over a thousand babies during her lifetime. When asked about her patients, Bennie reflected,"Most of the ones I went to were broke and in trouble--they couldn't afford to pay $300 to have thier babies born in a hospital. I couldn't turn my back on them. I swore an oath when I became a midwife that I'd help the ones that needed it, and that's what I done."

title: M. Joycelyn Elders: Personal Experiences in Medical School
description: M. Joycelyn Elders was born in Schaal, Arkansas (Howard County). In 1952 she graduated from Philander Smith College with a B.S. in Biology. The following year she enlisted in the U.S. Army as a physical therapist and obtained the rank of 2nd Lieutenant. After her discharge, she enrolled at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences obtaining her medical degree in 1962. Dr. Elders is certified as a pediatric endocrinologist. She is an expert in childhood sexual development and juvenile diabetes. In 1987, Governor Bill Clinton asked her to serve as the Director of the Arkansas Department of Health. Elders was the first African American and first woman to direct the Arkansas public health service, a position she held for six years (1987-1993). In 1993, President Bill Clinton appointed her Surgeon-General of the United States. She became the first African American woman to be appointed Surgeon General of the U.S. Public Health Service, serving until December 1994. A lifetime of service, Dr. Elders faced throughout her career the challenges of the onset of the HIV/AIDS disease and the highest rate of teen pregnancy in the industrialized world. She steadfastly pursued to raise the awareness of sexual education and successfully reduced the rate of teenage pregnancies throughout the country. Among her many achievements, Dr. Joycelyn Elders was inducted into the Arkansas Black Hall of Fame in 1995 and the Arkansas Womens Hall of Fame in 2016.

title: Mamie Phipps and Kenneth Clark, founders of the Northside Center for Child Development
description: Mamie Phipps Clark grew up in Hot Springs, Arkansas where she attended Langston High School. In 1934, after graduating at the age of seventeen, Clark was offered several scholarships to prominent black colleges. She chose Howard University in Washington D.C. majoring where she pursued studies in mathematics and physics. After graduating, Clark shifted her focus to psychology and enrolled in Columbia University, NY. In 1943, Clark completed her doctorate and was distinguished as being the first black woman to receive a degree in psychology at that institution. Her graduate research focused on the development of racial identity in children and was to prove influential in the Supreme Court ruling of Brown v Board of Education. In 1946, Dr. Clark and her husband opened the Northside Testing and Consultation Center in Harlem, New York. It was the first institutional practice in the area to offer psychological and casework services to local black families. In 1973, Mamie Phipps Clark was awarded the American Association of University Women Achievement Award and later the Candace Award for humanitarianism.

title: Kathryn Hall-Trujillo: Birthing Project USA
description: Dr. Kathryn Hall-Trujillo was born in Moscow, Arkansas (Jefferson County). She is a public health expert and advocate who focuses on healthcare for African American women. Hall-Trujillo received her M.A. in Public Health from the University of California at Los Angeles. In 1976, she worked as a public health administrator for the State of California. Seeing the difficulties that underserved women experienced in accessing quality health care, Hall-Trujillo established the Center for Community Health and Well-Being in 1988, a holistic health and social service agency based in Sacramento that housed a comprehensive health care clinic. Deriving from her work at the Center, Hall-Trujillo created the non-profit organization Birthing Project USA: The Underground Railroad for New Life, which has the goal of reducing infant mortality rates. From 1988 to 2010, her project helped 12,000 babies in over ninety-four communities in the United States, Canada, Cuba, Central America, and Africa. As faculty at the University of San Francisco, Dr. Hall-Trujillo is helping develop the Public Health Leadership Program for the Sacramento campus. In 2011, she was inducted into the Arkansas Black Hall of Fame.

title: Lena Lowe Jordan, R.N., Mosaic State Hospital
description: Lena Lowe Jordan was an African-American registered nurse and hospital administrator. In the 1920s, she moved to Little Rock, Arkansas from the state of Georgia and began her career as a registered nurse at the Mosaic State Hospital in 1927. In the 1930s, Lena Jordan became affiliated with the Arkansas Home and Hospital for Crippled Negro Children in Little Rock, AR. The hospital was the only charitable institution that cared for crippled black children and operated with a small budget. By 1936, in considerable financial troubles, Lena Jordan placed a mortgage on her own home to keep the hospital in operation. Subsequently, the institution was renamed the Lena Jordan Hospital by 1938. Her hospital was a twenty-bed facility equipped for general surgery, medical, and obstetric care. It was open to all black patients, regardless of their ability to pay. The physicians who made up her staff worked without pay and for charity. Notably, Lena Jordan created a program at her hospital to train new nurses. She provided the opportunity for young women to gain work experience at the hospital and obtain a practical nursing certificate for their service. Lena Jordan spent over thirty years caring for the poor and underserved communities of Little Rock, Arkansas.

description: Sophronia Reacie Williams worked as a nurse and nurse educator for forty-six years specializing in mental health. title: Group portrait of African-American Midwives in Forrest City, Arkansas
description: The Arkansas Board of Health took this group portrait of black midwives in Forrest City in 1929. Midwives are women specially trained to assist women in childbirth and were often called upon to deliver the baby in place of a doctor. A midwife was very knowledgeable about childbirth and the uses of medical herbs. Traditionally, Arkansas midwives learned their trade from another practicing midwife, quite often a family member. After the birth, a midwife took care of the newborn and attended to the recovery of the new mother. In the 1920s, under the Sheppard-Towner program, the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) issued permits to midwives who attended classes and were required to pass exams to practice midwifery. Midwives remain today vital care givers in a community.

title: Charolette Tidwell, founder of Antioch Youth and Family
description: Charlotte Tidwell is a longtime resident of Fort Smith, Arkansas. In 1965, Charlotte began her studies in nursing and became the first black woman to complete the nursing program at Sparks Hospital. For over thirty years she servered her community as a nurse and hospital administrator. Upon retirement, Charlotte Tidwell founded the non-profit Antioch Youth and Family. Her organization distributes nutrituous food to needing families throughout Western Arkansas and Eastern Oklahoma and has grown to be the largest food pantry throughout the region. While retired, Tidwell considers that she is still following her calling as a nurse by addressing food insecurity in the community. She says,"The work has nothing to do with Charlotte. title: Barbara Johnson, UAMS Med Tech
description: Barbara Johnson was born in Hot Springs, Arkansas. She received her B.S. in Nursing in 1955 from the Meharry Medical College, School of Nursing in Nashville, TN. In 1972, she graduated from the University of Central Arkansas with a M.S. in Education and a M.S. in Nursing. She began her nursing career at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences. From 1960-1965, Barbara Johnson became the first black woman to hold the position of Operating Room head nurse. In 1966, she became the Director of Medical Services for the OEO Headstart program, and afterward joined the nursing staff of the Veterans Administration Hospital. In 1975, Governor Dale Bumpers appointed Barbara Johnson as head of the Arkansas State Board of Health of which she was the first African-American woman to become president of that organization. In 1980, she was an active member of the Little Rock Black Nurses Association and served as Corresponding Secretary. From 1991-2014 she was a Continuing Education Consultant for the Arkansas State Nurses Association, Individual Educational Activity Program. Barbara Johnson is an ARNA Hall of Fame Inductee.

title: Maud Hines in Red Cross uniform, 1918
description: At the outset of World War I, African-American women sought inclusion in the US Army Nurse Corps to serve in the war effort. Some did so due to patriotic fervor while others wished to demonstrate that were loyal Americans who deserved the full benefits of citizenship. They faced exceptional barriers due to societal views on sex and race. It was not until July 1918 that African-American women were included as reserve nurses in the American Red Cross. They were allowed to contribute strictly as reserve in case of emergency. That crisis occurred in October 1918 with the outbreak of the Spanish Influenza. In the face of pandemic, black nurses were badly needed to tend to the sick. Maud Hines was one such nurse who was deployed to combat the viral outbreak at Camp Pike in Little Rock, Arkansas.

description: Freda McKissic Bush, M.D., is an obstetrician/gynecologist with long experience in addressing issues of women's health. title: Stories from the Archives (Episode 2): Mamie O. Hale, R.N.
description: Mamie Odessa Hale was born November 19, 1910 in Keeny's Creek, WV. She completed her early medical education at Freedman's Hospital, School of Nursing in Washington, D.C., and then worked for a time with the county health unit for the Works Progress Administration in Fayette County, WV. Prior to beginning her new career in Arkansas, she took a course on midwifery at the Tuskegee Institute in Tuskegee, AL. In 1942, Mamie Hale arrived in Arkansas where she helped local nurses administer midwife educational programs for the Crittenden County Health Department. By 1945, she was appointed as midwife consultant by the Arkansas Department of Health. Nurse Hale was responsible for the training of midwives across the state ensuring that they knew the proper techniques to manage the medical aspects of pregnancy. From 1945 to 1950, Mamie Hale initiated educational programs throughout Conway, Faulkner, Lonoke, and St. Francis counties. title: Dr. Florence Char, UAMS Pediatrian and Geneticist
description: Florence Char was born in Peking, China on April 7, 1923. By the early 1940s, her parents sent Florence and her brother to live in the western United States. Dr. Char earned her medical degree at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn in 1952. She interned in Pediatrics at the University of Minnesota Hospitals from 1952-53 and was a fellow in Pediatric Cardiology in 1955-1957. She was certified in Pediatrics in 1959 and Pediatric Cardiology in 1965. She joined the faculty at the University of Arkansas School of Medicine in 1963. In 1971, Dr. Char established the first genetics clinics and cytogenetics laboratory in Arkansas and was instrumental in the creation of the Arkansas Genetics Program at UAMS. In 1978, Dr. Char described a genetic birth defect that came to be called Char syndrome. She retired in 1990 with the rank of professor emeritus.

title: Scenes from Midwife School at J.S. Phelix High School in Marion, AR
description: Group photograph of African-American women studying techinques of midwifery at J.S. Phelix high school in Marion, Arkansas. Midwives are people specially trained to assist women in childbirth and were often called upon to deliver the baby in place of a doctor. A midwife was very knowledgeable about childbirth and the uses of medical herbs. Traditionally, Arkansas midwives learned their trade from another practicing midwife, quite often a family member. After the birth, a midwife took care of the newborn and attended to the recovery of the new mother. In the 1920s, under the Sheppard-Towner program, the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) issued permits to midwives who attended classes and were required to pass exams to practice midwifery. Midwives remain today vital care givers in a community.

title: Kathryn Hall-Trujillo, Arkansas Black Hall of Fame
description: Dr. Kathryn Hall-Trujillo was born in Moscow, Arkansas (Jefferson County). She is a public health expert and advocate who focuses on healthcare for African American women. Hall-Trujillo received her M.A. in Public Health from the University of California at Los Angeles. In 1976, she worked as a public health administrator for the State of California. Seeing the difficulties that underserved women experienced in accessing quality health care, Hall-Trujillo established the Center for Community Health and Well-Being in 1988, a holistic health and social service agency based in Sacramento that housed a comprehensive health care clinic. Deriving from her work at the Center, Hall-Trujillo created the non-profit organization Birthing Project USA: The Underground Railroad for New Life, which has the goal of reducing infant mortality rates. From 1988 to 2010, her project helped 12,000 babies in over ninety-four communities in the United States, Canada, Cuba, Central America, and Africa. As faculty at the University of San Francisco, Dr. Hall-Trujillo is helping develop the Public Health Leadership Program for the Sacramento campus. In 2011, she was inducted into the Arkansas Black Hall of Fame.

title: Marjorie Wilkins Williams, Silas Hunt Legacy Award Recipient
description: Marjorie Wilkins Williams grew up in Little Rock, Arkansas. When she heard that the University of Arkansas would admit African Americans to a new nursing program, she decided to pursue the opportunity. She enrolled in the College of Nursing at the University of Arkansas in 1955 and was one of three undergraduates to integrate the university. Williams attended the UA for four years and graduated with a B.S. in nursing. She received an M.S. in guidance and counseling from Troy State University in 1972, and later completed an MS in nursing from the University of Texas Health Science Center in 1977. Williams has taught nursing at the San Antonio College for thirty years and was also faculty at Troy State University. She has worked in the medical field as a general staff and operating room nurse. In 1998, the UA Black Alumni Society invited Marjorie Williams, Maxine Sutton, and Billie Rose Whitfield Jacobs to receive the Living Legacy Pioneer Award. In 2012, Marjorie Wilkins Williams received the Silas Hunt Legacy Award in recognition of her career and achievements.

title: Dr. Lidia Gertrudis Sogandares, President of the National Medical Association
description: A citizen of the Republic of Panama, Dr. Lidia Gertrudis Sogandares was the first Latin American graduate of the University of Arkansas School of Medicine. She is renown as the first female doctor in Panama and Central America. In 1934, Lidia Sogandares graduated from UAMS with a degree in medicine. She completed residency at the Women's Hospital in Philadelphia, where she specialized in the fields of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Returning to Panama, Dr. Sogandares joined the medical staff at Santos Tomas Hospital and gradually rose to the position of Chief of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Over the course of her career, Sogandares published several gynecological studies and was affiliated with many professional organizations. Dr. Lidia G. Sogandares was co-founder and first female member of the Panamanian Academy of Medicine and Surgery; She was a co-founder and the first president of the Panamanian Society of Obstetrics and Gynecology, a member of the Pan-American Alliance of Medical Women, the Isthmian Medical Association of the Canal Zone, and the Women Medical Association.

title: Dr. Pao-Feng Tsai, UAMS College of Nursing
description: Pao-Feng Tsai, PhD, RN is a professor at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) College of Nursing. She received her B.S. in Nursing in 1984 at the Kaohsiung Medical College School of Nursing and, in 1987, she earned an M.S. in Public Health at the Institute of Public Health, National Yang-Ming Medical College in Taiwan. In 1996-98, she earned her M.S. and doctorate in Nursing at Wayne State University College of Nursing. In 1999, Dr. Tsai began her career at UAMS as an associate professor and became a professor in 2013. She has also served as an adjunct professor for geriatrics from 2002-2005. Dr. Tsai has focused her research on geriatric pain care using alternative therapies. She holds the Alice An-Loh Sun Endowed Professorship in Geriatric Nursing. Tsai is a member of the International Association for the Study of Pain, American Pain Society, Arkansas Nurses Association, Southern Nursing Research Society, Gerontological Society of America, and Sigma Theta Tau International Honor Society of Nursing.

title: Lenora Newsome, P.D., President of the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy
description: Lenora Newsome, P.D., is from the small town of Smackover, AR and is a graduate of the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) College of Pharmacy. During her career, she has experienced many changes to the practice including the implementation of new technology. While practicing pharmacy in El Dorado, AR, she helped True Quality Pharmacies open their first pharmacy in the state. In 1991, Newsome was appointed to the Arkansas State Board of Pharmacy by Governor Bill Clinton and she has been appointed to that position by each successive Arkansas governor. She had served the state practicing pharmacy in rural communities for almost forty years. Newsome is a member of the Arkansas Pharmacist Association and has served as a board member for the South Arkansas Regional Health Center. In 2015, she was honored with the Percy Malone Award for Public Service by the Arkansas Pharmacists Association. Newsome currently serves as president of the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy.

title: Dr. Medha Munshi, Geriatrician and Endocrinologist
description: Medha Munshi, M.D., received her medical degree from the Baroda Medical College in Vadodara, Taiwan. She undertook her residency at the Indiana University Health Ball Memorial Hospital. From 1992-1999, she completed two fellowships at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences pursuing studies in Endocrinology, Diabetes, and Internal Medicine. Dr. Medha Munshi is the Director of the Joslin Geriatric Diabetes Program and an Associate Professor of Medicine at the Harvard Medical School. She practices primary care geriatrics at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical center. Dr. Munshi is board certified in Internal Medicine, Geriatric Medicine, and Endocrinology and Metabolism. Her clinical research is focused on identifying barriers to diabetes management and developing new strategies for improving care for older adults.

title: Dr. Patricia A. Newton, UAMS Student
description: Patricia A. Newton, M.D., M.H.P., M.A. was born in Tuckerman, Arkansas. She was the medical director, a former president, and founding member of the Black Psychiatrists of America (BPA). She was one of the first APA/NIMH Fellows and the first woman chair of the Department of Psychiatry at Provident Hospital in Baltimore. Dr. Newton also served as academic faculty at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine for over sixteen years. Her clinical work centered on anxiety disorders with a special focus on posttraumatic stress disorder, as well as depression and chronic mental illness. Dr. Newton was renowned for her pioneering work integrating African spirituality into Black mental health and for working with health care professionals in Africa and the Caribbean as well as in the United States.

title: Larronda Rainey, UAMS College of Nursing
description: Lorronda M. Rainey, M.N.Sc, RN, began her career in the College of Nursing at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences in 1999. Entering graduate studies, she focused on Nursing Education and has been an instructor for the past fifteen years. Rainey has worked on a variety of grants providing full tuition and support for five hundred students receiving education and training as certified assistants, licensed practical nurses, and registered nurses. In addition, she facilitated the development of the first online training programs for individuals in nursing education in the state of Arkansas. This training comprised over two-hundred participants, significantly contributing to the number of nurses qualified to serve as future nurse educators in the state. Reflating on her nursing career, she notes,"I always knew I wanted to teach. When I first started out in nursing, one of my five-year goals was to be an educator." In 2019 Lorronda Rainey was awarded the PCI Nurse Educator of the Year award.
